title: Should I Teach Math Differently Than the School Does?
description: Navigating the challenge when your math methods conflict with how your child is learning at school.
imageAlt: Parent confused by child's math homework

content.intro: Your child brings home math homework and you don't recognize the method. "Why don't they just do it the normal way?" Here's what's going on and how to handle it.

sections.text: Modern math education (sometimes called "Common Core math" in the US) emphasizes:

items: Understanding WHY procedures work, not just HOW

sections.text: The "old" way (standard algorithms) is still taught – but after building conceptual understanding.
The Problem with Teaching Your Way

rows: Two different methods for the same thing is overwhelming
Child thinks teacher's method is wrong
Your shortcut skips the conceptual learning
Child can't show work the expected way

sections.text: Ask your child to teach you. Watch Khan Academy or YouTube videos on Common Core methods. Most methods make sense once you understand the reasoning.
Instead of showing them "the right way," ask: "What did your teacher show you?" "What's the first step?" Help them use their method, not yours.
If you're confused, ask how you can support at home. Teachers often have parent guides or can explain the reasoning.
You don't need to understand every method to support your child. Be present, encourage effort, and let the teacher teach.
Eventually, your child will likely learn the standard algorithms too. The "strange" methods are building number sense that makes the standard methods make more sense.

items: After your child has learned the school method
As an additional strategy (not a replacement)
When doing mental math together in daily life
When the child initiates curiosity about other methods

faq.question: Is "new math" actually better?
faq.answer: Research supports teaching for understanding before procedures. The methods look strange but develop number sense that serves kids long-term. Traditional methods are still taught – just after conceptual foundation.

faq.question: What if I really think the teacher's method is worse?
faq.answer: Keep it to yourself. Different doesn't mean worse. Undermining the teacher damages your child's learning. Save discussions for parent-teacher conferences.

faq.question: My child gets the right answer with my method. Isn't that enough?
faq.answer: Getting right answers matters, but understanding matters more for future learning. A child who only knows procedures struggles when math gets abstract in middle school.
